data.text: Energy Drain during a Bicycle Tour

Want to pick your brains again‚Ä¶doing my first 2 weeks tour soon. Have the kit and did my longest ride of 90 miles with it yesterday. But energy in middle was tough, how do you all fuel up? May sound silly but was worried eating too much would impact how I felt back on bike

If you're doing a big day cycling then eat whatever you want or need üòä On my biggest day cycle ( 209 miles ) I took few cheese sandwiches, but my basic fuel was sweets, the next day I went back to proper food. Strava estimated I used 13000 calories, I think lots of sweets are the only way to carry and easily consume that amount of calories
data.author: Alan Tucker

data.text: that is awesome distance! Thanks

I use crank sports gels and mix for electrolytes . No stomach issues or dehydration Cranksports.com

data.author: Steven Orton

data.text: I always eat lots of carbs in the evening, in the morning I just have coffee. Then fruit or dried fruit...better still if you can pick them as you tour. If it's hot and long days I eat bread and cheese then sleep it off for an hour or so. In the winter I have an energy drink when my energy is low....then coffee, a few more miles and then a beer and a few more miles. As I stealth camp I like to keep going until the last of the light.
data.author: Matthew Adams

data.text: Carb up and pay attention to your energy as you go. If you allow yourself to get hungry or thirsty, it's already too late. Eat small amounts every 30 to 60 minutes.
data.author: Ryan Jeambey

data.text: thanks I probably didn‚Äôt do enough of either, miles where ok though
data.author: Steven Orton

data.text: that's great advice üëç
data.author: Parag Shah

data.text: On a couple of toures of Southern Ireland we drank Murpys stout every day and unsurprisingly our daily distance steadily decreased.
data.author: Steven Offord

data.text: bet the distance you talked about steadily increased though:) best way to see Ireland
data.author: Steven Orton

data.text: but I bet you enjoyed it!
data.author: John Goldman

data.text: On one trip I was travelling with folk musicians who seemed to have planned the route around small pub based folk sessions.

data.text: must have been amazing
data.author: Steven Orton

data.text: My memories are hazy.
data.author: Steven Offord

data.text: Take breaks....my friend told me to take 15 for every hour, so if I rode for 3 hours, 45 minute break....it worked for me....he has 27 cross country trips..
data.author: Paul Rodriguez

data.text: 15 breaks an hour...that sounds like my kind of touring pace!
data.author: Steven Offord

data.text: üòÇüòÇüòÇüòÇüòÇüòÇ
data.author: Paul Rodriguez

data.text: Eat regularly take breaks
data.author: John Axson

data.text: Natural foods are better than the gel packs or other such energy boosters. They absorb slower and may be easier to regulate over long periods of time. Eat to satisfaction not fullness. Like Ryan said, small amounts - hand full size may be a good measure. Boosters, while convenient burn off faster but, can be a good source to tackle a challenging hurdle like the final stretch over a hill or mountain. Also don't ignore hydration it may be more important and will help reduce imflamation and muscle fatigue aiding in better overnight recovery. Pace may also be a factor to determine how frequent you need to eat and hydrate. The more strained, the more often but hydrate at least every 15 mins not matter what it is. Your urine should be clear.
data.author: Ed Melby

data.text: The energy burn off is roughly the same rate as it's intake - so if you eat sweets or gels that boost your sugar level quickly (high GI) then your energy will drop quickly too. If you take low GI carbs, like porridge, it builds up and drops slower. There's a team chef called Hannah Grant who does some excellent videos on this. You may be better off with a coffee break and a flapjack than a gel.
data.author: Simon Thompson

data.text: I eat regular food as much as possible, and eat only enough to be satisfied. Never any more than that. If you reach a town with grocery store buy a box of strawberries or blueberries or grapes etc and eat 'em up. Not a lot of substance but it's great for your soul--you feel so good no hill is a problem!
data.author: Ken Knight

data.text: I think gels and water mixes packs are maybe not for everyone, but they definitely are for me. I prefer CrankSports products. I can't eat very much on long rides, so dropping a gel every 45 min or so with plenty of water works. (Boring? Yep. After about 4-5 hours I'm tired of them) You have to find out what works best for you, and that's going to take experimentation. The "you should do or eat this or that" is not based on data, and is only useful as a suggestion. Also, don't forget to watch hydration. Best way to find out how you're doing is to weigh yourself before and after a ride, which will give you a hint as to how much water you're losing. Understanding how many calories you burn on a ride will also give you an idea of how much fuel to replace.
data.author: Greg Gautreaux

data.text: thanks I am looking for suggestions to work from the crank sports look good as someone else mentioned them too but don‚Äôt ship to uk
data.author: Steven Orton

data.text: Hammer gel is the only other one off the top of my head that uses Maltodextrin as the main ingredient. Worth a look, probably more expensive.

data.author: Steven Orton

data.text: I use honey stinger gels. I‚Äôve also found that taking a 10 minute break every ~2 hours of cycling helps a lot. I don‚Äôt eat much while on tour as heavy foods upset my stomach and make it hard to ride. It‚Äôs hard to eat healthy on tour. It‚Äôs the only time I don‚Äôt feel guilty eating fast food cause it‚Äôs a lot of calories and you‚Äôll burn a lot.
data.author: Ty Dawley

data.text: that is one of my concerns with big food. Will check out the gels
data.author: Steven Orton

data.text: Eat real food, stay away from sugary things, including fizzy drinks. The energy spike is short-lived and all it does is create a craving. It is very difficult to do, especially if you are reliant on small-town cafes for refueling.
data.author: Annie Mtb North

data.text: , if you eat sugary stuff at a constant rate ( ie the same rate that you're using it ) then there is no 'energy spike'
data.author: Alan Tucker

data.text: that becomes a craving/addiction. Sugary stuff is of no nutrient value. Eat fruits etc. Nutrients are neglected on endurance rides. A quick fix seems the choice but then runny and upset guts are guaranteed
data.author: Annie Mtb North

data.text: well it works for me, and I have no problem with runny and upset guts üòä,
data.author: Alan Tucker

data.text: Carb up? easy for some but Keto high fat low carb is the best for some of us as not everyone can process carbs . Nibbling constantly , tippling water every 15 minutes works for many of us. The fact you did 90 miles is not something to be proud of on a tour . Yes it is impressive but a tour is not a race or an endurance event , it should be a look and see what is around us , ride.
data.author: Bob Loblawb

data.text: I wasn‚Äôt boasting I was saying I did it and wanted people s advice. I have never done that distance before so never have had to think about fuel
data.author: Steven Orton

data.text: Boasting probably not the best word. Distance per day should be less ,as that makes your ride better . I made the little boo boo of not realizing my cycling partner was a destination tourist and not a sight seeing tourist on one of my tours. However as you said " fuel " that is a harder question to answer as personally I can not process Carbs to get the energy required for distance but being on the Keto diet I seem to have better energy, endurance , and go longer between meals with hydration being very important between said nibbles. You need something to chew on that takes time to be digested , giving you the full feeling longer. There be the problem of what works for you may not work at all for me.
data.author: Bob Loblawb

data.text: definitely going for scenery but really concerned about not feeling cack after eating, as had some issues with wheat in past..really looking at what others are doing as a base to try and find what works for me. Had some really interesting suggestions so thanks‚Ä¶and I will definitely be enjoying the view and a chat:)
data.author: Steven Orton

data.text: I like trail mix the best. Sometimes I grab a couple protein or Clif bars for calories if lunch will not be readily available.Most important thing though is I carry 3 water bottles. 1 with Nuun because it has electrolytes and sodium. 2 with plain water. I stop at least once an hour to eat a little and drink. I also carry Nuun instant in case I really lose steam. That is like getting a jump start! Getting enough water in is critical.
data.author: John Goldman

data.text: Nothing is as real as an actual meal. I always eat before I ride and eat again if I'm riding more than four hours. Cheap granola bars and/or peanuts can hold me over for an extra hour or two. I also drink a dilute drink mix instead of water to keep both energy and electrolytes up.
data.author: Gordo S. Groundchuck

data.text: I eat light but often while riding and eat ALOT at the end of the day
data.author: Scout Ess

data.text: I always have a big breakfast, either oatmeal or highhfat Greek yoghurt with fruits and some seeds n stuff. Also clean and cut up some veg and fruits for snacks in advance and boil a few eggs. For lunch I usually have something that's high in salt, fat, protein and carbs, like a cheese and egg sandwich. For tee usually fry some veg and beans and maybe put that on some burrito's or get a ready-made pasta you can heat up. Also, someone I know said that a (skimmed) chocolate milk after a day of cycling works wonders for your recovery. Haven't tried that yet, but I will on my next trip.
data.author: Jessica Kittle

data.text: sounds lovely
data.author: Steven Orton

data.text: chocolate milk is excellent recovery drink too
data.author: Steven Orton

data.text: I used to love that when I was little, but I think my lactase secretion may not be what it was.
data.author: Steven Offord

data.text: I need microbes to do it for me. Give me cheese or yogurt. Actually a drinking yougurt sounds great for recovery, with the advantage that if it's a live lactobacillus culture, it doesn't even need refrigeration as the lactic acid prevents spoilage bacteria from being able to establish. Other lactofermented products similarly self preserve; pickles anybody?
data.author: Steven Offord

data.text: I use symprove which is amazing but does need a fridge so can‚Äôt take it:(
data.author: Steven Orton

data.text: Most supermarket own brand plain yogurts are live culture, though many don't bother to print that they are on the pack. I try to buy them on their sell by then let them mature further.
data.author: Steven Offord

data.text: I pack hard boiled eggs and salt/pepper sashes, apples/carrots with cheese/peanut butter, dates & almonds for regular injections of protein throughout my day. Agree small meals works best
data.author: Barbara Appleby
